I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  2004  Pakistan  country  strategy  and  program  update  (CSPU)  of  the  Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  reaffirms  the  strategy  of  supporting  good  governance,  pro-poor 
economic growth, and inclusive social development, with a major focus on good governance. 
The CSPU commits ADB to deepening ongoing assistance in support of governance reforms by 
(i) “decentralizing” assistance to the province level; (ii) ensuring that design of ADB projects is 
consistent with the new governance structures and procedures created under laws concerned 
with devolution and related reforms; and (iii) supporting the Government’s efforts to ensure 
better coordination of external funding agencies at the operational level, particularly including 
provincial  and  local  governments.  This  advisory  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  assist  the 
Government and ADB to meet these commitments.  
 
2.  The volume of ADB lending impacted by devolution places unprecedented demands on 
the  Government,  ADB  mission  leaders,  and  Pakistan  Resident  Mission  (PRM).  The  TA  is 
designed to help the Government align and coordinate its operations, including those financed 
by external funding agencies, with policy on devolution, gender, and social development. The 
objective, purpose, scope, implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and 
terms of reference of the TA2 were designed during dialogue with the Government and donor 
partners  for  the  CSPU  (March-May  2003)  and  subsequently  refined  during  preparation  of 
lending operations (January-May 2004). The TA framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Devolution Reform and Poverty Reduction. The federal Government published the 
poverty reduction strategy paper (PRSP)3 in December 2003, and provincial governments have 
published  draft  PRSPs.  Devolution  is  central  to  the  federal  and  all  provincial  PRSPs. 
Responsibility for delivery of the bulk of social and productive services and for regulation of civil 
society,  natural  resources,  labor,  and  commercial  activity  has  been  devolved  to  local 
governments.  New laws in support of devolution also provide an unprecedented opportunity for 
improving relations between governments and organized elements of civil society in all aspects 
of  service  delivery,  justice,  and  social  regulation  at  the  local  level.  Major  reorientation  of 
provincial governments is also required now to ensure their effective policy, fiscal, technical, and 
regulatory support for service delivery. The challenge for donors is to ensure that support for the 
PRSP  is  delivered  in  a  manner  consistent  with  the  new  local  institutional  arrangements, 
systems, and procedures created under the local government ordinances (LGOs) 2001, the 
Police Order 2002, and associated legislation governing justice, civil society, gender, and social 
development. In the past, the Government relied on donor assistance for approximately 60% of 
its development spending. Failure to quickly realign donor assistance modalities could both 
delay  and  disrupt  the  capacity  building  necessary  for  provincial  and  local  governments  to 
assume the new responsibilities and accountabilities envisaged under devolution. In turn, this 
risks public dissatisfaction with the progress of devolution and could undermine implementation 
of the poverty reduction strategy.  
 
4.  Implications of ADB’s Devolution Focus and Provincial Strategy. PRM’s assistance 
to the poverty reduction strategy has placed ADB in a leading role in the donor community’s 
support for poverty reduction through governance reforms. During 2001 and 2002, the ADB

Board of Directors approved two major program loans to governance reforms in Pakistan, both 
of which are classified as core poverty interventions: the Access to Justice Program4 (AJP) and 
the Decentralization Support Program5 (DSP). Through these programs, ADB is also engaged in 
a  range  of  new  initiatives  with  civil  society,  especially  Pakistan’s  nongovernmental 
organizations, to build a broad-based constituency for these reforms and to help them capitalize 
on new opportunities for relations between states civil society provided for in the LGOs and PO, 
as well as associated legislation governing consumer rights, freedom of information, defamation 
and contempt, pro-poor law reform, management of environmental assets, and promotion of 
human rights.  
 
5.  Recently, ADB and the Government agreed to prepare and implement province-focused 
public sector reform programs as part of a wider strategy to establish policy dialogue and 
partnerships at the provincial level and to consolidate support to devolution: the ongoing Punjab 
Public Resource Management Program6 and the proposed Balochistan resource management 
program.7  These  programs  will  also  impact  directly  on  ADB’s  assistance8  to  the  health, 
education, water and sanitation, and rural development sectors by helping define the planning, 
fiscal, and regulatory arrangements through which the province will communicate its policy 
priorities to local governments. ADB will also assist the four provincial devolved social services 
programs  (DSSP)  (Sindh  2003,  Punjab  2004,  Balochistan  2005,  and  North-West  Frontier 
Province  2006)  that  aim  to  strengthen  provincial  and  local  government  commitments  to 
improved social service delivery. As a result of the CSPU refinement of ADB’s strategy, the 
share of governance programs in the total lending program has increased from 9% in the 
country strategy and program to 23% in the CSPU, and 45–55% of all lending will be affected by 
the commitment to design all future ADB projects in a manner consistent with devolution and to 
build effective province-focused support.  
 
6.  The Government has recently announced a donor coordination strategy. The TA will (i) 
help the planning and coordination agencies of federal and provincial governments develop  
innovative strategies and operations to implement investment projects; (ii) provide technical and 
capacity-building  support  to  provincial  and  local  governments,  whose  skillful  adoption  and 
implementation of the new devolved systems will be crucial to the success of the larger poverty 
reduction strategy; and (iii) help the Government refine the donor coordination strategy and 
realign the ongoing external assistance to the imperatives of devolution. The TA’s stakeholders 
will include private-sector service providers, civil society, community-based organizations, and

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Outputs 
7.  The objective of the TA is to help integrate donor-supported poverty reduction and 
governance reform initiatives at the program and project levels. The TA will have three primary 
outputs:  (i) better coordination and alignment at the provincial levels for new and existing 
projects  in  key  PRSP  sectors  (e.g.,  health,  education,  water  and  sanitation,  and  rural 
development):  (ii)  greater  consistency  between  devolution  policy  and  procedures  and  the 
institutional  and  financial  design  features  of  ADB  ongoing  and  pipeline  TA  and  lending 
operations: and (iii) manuals, guides, and training events for sector managers and policymakers 
in the Government.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.   The TA will augment the capacity of the federal Planning Commission (PC) and the 
provincial planning and development departments (P&D) to coordinate and monitor the effective 
use of external development assistance supporting the devolution plan. The TA will supplement 
provincial program support offices (PPSO) created under the DSP to provide technical advice to 
the P&Ds and line departments supporting local government delivery of devolved services. This 
association between the TA and DSP will ensure direct linkage between the systems and 
procedures for devolution developed under the DSP and key sector operations that are the 
focus of the TA. The TA will engage expertise to  (i) manage programs in support of poverty 
reduction and devolution reforms in the provinces, including design of intergovernmental fiscal 
and other institutional arrangements; (ii) review and contribute to the design of sector-wide 
reform  strategies  (in  particular,  for  health,  education,  water  and  sanitation,  and  rural 
development)  consistent  with  devolution;  and  (iii)  establish  databases  and  coordinative 
arrangements to help provincial governments realign vertical programs to devolution policy and 
procedures.   
 
9.  Domestic consultants in long-term provincial positions and short-term resource persons 
with considerable experience in key sectors will be engaged to provide technical support to 
federal  and  provincial  governments,  as  required,  in  aligning  development  operations  to 
devolution. In particular, the TA will help build operational liaison between the DSP, DSSPs, and 
other ADB programs in support of public resource management and devolved service delivery.9 
A technical support pool will allow the Government to respond to particular issues requiring 
intensive  coordination  and  problem  solving,  as  well  as  provide  training  and  capacity 
development support.  
  
1.  Component 1: Poverty and Governance Reform Program Management 
 
10.  A key responsibility of the P&Ds is to support intergovernmental linkages and overall 
coherence in administering development assistance to provincial and local governments. The 
key areas for support at the provincial level are (i) poverty reduction, devolution, and local 
government  reforms;  (ii)  intergovernmental  fiscal  restructuring,  revenue  management,  and 
expenditure planning; (iii) physical asset management; (iv) technical assistance management, 
                                                 
9 The operational details will be worked out during the inception mission.

4    
focusing on capacity development; and (v) gender mainstreaming through devolution reforms. 
To enhance the P&Ds’ capacity, the TA will engage long-term domestic consultants in each 
province to provide expertise in these five areas to government officials responsible for ADB’s 
ongoing and pipeline TA and lending operations from 2004 to 2006. Their ongoing operations 
will be coordinated by the program director, PPSO of the DSP.  
 
2.  Component 2: Sector-wide Reform Strategies and Operations 
 
11.  Existing arrangements for planning, budgeting, and financing service delivery need to be 
reoriented from a vertical program approach (wherein delivery arrangements are controlled by 
federal and provincial agencies) to one governed through intergovernmental fiscal transfer rules 
and  procedures  in  support  of  local  government  service  delivery.10  While  the  LGOs  define 
responsibilities of local governments and mandate province finance commissions (PFCs) to 
design  and  monitor  these  new  intergovernmental  fiscal  arrangements,  the  LGOs  do  not 
explicitly stipulate the new corresponding roles of provincial governments. Although provinces 
no longer have the power to command and control the delivery performance of local authorities, 
it is not clear how to reform existing sector policy, planning, and financing arrangements in a 
way that is consistent with devolution and allows provinces to effectively communicate their 
policy priorities. However, provincial departments are beginning to introduce sector-wide policy11 
and donor coordination approaches that need further encouragement and linkage with PRSP 
commitments and medium-term budget frameworks.  
 
12.  Short-term  inputs  will  be  provided  by  various  resource  persons  under  a  technical 
resource pool to (i) help the Government review existing provincial institutional arrangements for 
planning, financing, and delivering social services; (ii) help PFCs design modalities for fund flow 
management, thereby aiding the transition from a vertical program to an intergovernmental 
grant system approach; and (iii) provide basic orientation to enable government officials to 
incorporate the changed approaches in design and implementation.  
 
3.  Component 3: Operational and Design Support  
13.  This component will provide government official’s direct support to address the CSPU 
commitment  to  design  pipeline  lending  and  to  revisit  recently  approved  lending  to  ensure 
consistency with devolution policy, laws, and procedures. This component will help the PC and 
provincial P&Ds maintain accurate databases of donor activities to support policy dialogue and 
design of province-wide donor coordination strategy for sector-wide and specific large-scale 
multidonor programs. Such institutional realignment also requires civil-society engagement to 
ensure sustained policy dialogue and build ownership for ongoing reforms. Of particular note 
are two imperatives: (i) strengthening coordination between the federal and provincial planning 
agencies and civil society; and (ii) facilitating tripartite linkages between the Government, ADB, 
and civil society. At the provincial level, these imperatives will be addressed through civil-society 
coordinators who will organize, facilitate, and document project-specific consultations. The TA 
will assist provincial P&Ds by engaging short-term civil-society coordinators in the provinces to 
facilitate ADB-Government-civil-society cooperation and policy exchange and help refine ADB’s 
ongoing and pipeline operations from 2004 to 2006.

14.  Precise details of the priority activities to be supported in each province will be defined 
through periodic consultation with the PC and P&Ds, in the context of the ongoing DSP and 
DSSP  quarterly  work-planning  process  and  annual  performance  reviews  (APRs).  This  will 
ensure that consultant inputs are closely linked with actual priorities.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $560,000 equivalent, comprising all local currency. ADB’s 
TA funding program will finance $450,000 of this on a grant basis, and the Government will 
contribute the remaining local currency of $110,000 equivalent to provide office accommodation, 
counterpart staff, facilities for seminars and meetings, and administrative support. Appendix 2 
summarizes the cost estimates.                                                                                                                               
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements  
16.  The PC will be the Executing Agency for the TA and the provincial P&Ds will be the 
implementing agencies. The PC has nominated as TA project director a senior official who 
represents the PC on the DSP national program steering committee (NPSC). An inception 
mission and quarterly meetings of the PC, consultants engaged under the TA, the chair of the 
NPSC, and ADB, chaired by the PC, will review TA implementation progress. The quality of 
outputs from the TA consultants will be evaluated through the standard consultant annual 
personnel performance review and the APR process. 
 
17.  The TA is scheduled to be implemented over 18 months, from December 2004 to June 
2006. A team of domestic consultants will provide a total of 80 person-months of consulting 
services. The consultants will be engaged by ADB on an individual basis in accordance with its 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the 
engagement of domestic consultants. Outline terms of reference are in Appendix 3. The team 
will  be  managed  by  the  team  leader  of  TA  4207–PAK:  Support  to  Implementation  of 
Decentralization II (SID II) who will be responsible for the quality of consultants’ performance. 
Modifications to the scope, terms, and activities of consultants recruited under this TA will be 
decided jointly by the team leader of TA 4207-PAK and the TA project director. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
18.       The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $450,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Pakistan for Strengthening Coordination and Alignment of Government 
Operations to Devolution, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The Government of Pakistan is mobilizing and directing an unprecedented array of 
technical, institutional, and fiscal resources in support of devolution in the context of its poverty 
reduction strategy paper (PRSP). Direct support from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to 
this process is through the Decentralization Support Program (DSP) and Access to Justice 
Program (AJP) at federal level, and public-sector resource-management programs in the Punjab 
and Balochistan. ADB is committed to ensuring that all future TA and lending operations will 
support and be consistent with devolution. ADB has agreed to revisit recently approved lending 
projects to determine whether redesign of these projects is warranted. 
 
2.  The  TA  will  augment  existing  professional  resources  available  to  key  federal  and 
provincial agencies1 and, in particular, integrate with teams comprising program support offices 
at  the  federal  level  and  in  each  province  established  to  implement  the  DSP.  The  tasks 
supported under this TA will be performed by a team of domestic consultants: (i) four province 
reform specialists; (ii) various sector reform specialists to be deployed short term on a demand 
basis;  (iii)  a  procurement  and  administration  specialist;  and  (iv)  3  provincial  civil-society 
coordinators. A modest pool of resources has been allocated and will be deployed to provide 
short-term expertise on the basis of requirements identified during the annual performance 
review (APR).   
 
3.  Consultants recruited under the TA will report to the team leader, SID II (TA 4207-PAK).2 
Modifications to the scope, terms, and activities of consultants recruited under the TA will be 
decided jointly by the TA 4207-PAK team leader and TA project director.  
 
4.  Each consultant’s input will be directed around the three components of the TA (i) 
poverty and government reform program management; (ii) sector-wide reform strategies and 
operations; and (iii) operational and design support.  
 
5.  The terms of reference for each position are outlined as follows. They will be further 
refined by the TA 4207-PAK: team leader, in consultation with the Executing Agency and ADB, 
within 3 months of the start of the assignment.  
 
A.  Province Reform Specialists 
 
6.  Province Reform Specialists3 (4 positions; 1 each for the duty station in Islamabad 
(also supporting NWFP P&D Peshawar), Quetta, Lahore, and Karachi; 40 person-months total). 
Responsibilities include the following: 
 
(i)  Review  all  relevant  documentation  relating  to  devolution  specifically  that 
concerned with local government and intergovernmental relations, produced by 
government agencies, Pakistan’s aid partners, and public commentators; 
(ii)  Identify and document all existing external agency funded program and projects 
with either federal or provincial executing agencies concerning health, education, 
water  and  sanitation,  and  rural  development  in  the  assigned  province.

B.    Sector Reform Specialists 
 
7.  Social  Sector,  Municipal  Services,  Roads,  and  Local  Infrastructure  (8  person-
months total).  These  consultant  inputs  will  be  engaged  on a  demand  basis,  with terms  of

(i)  Analyze  and  chart  the  assignments  of  responsibility  for  policy;  planning; 
regulation  and  standards;  and  budget,  procurement,  and  expenditure  control 
functions  envisaged  in  the  local  government  ordinances  and  associated 
legislation (budget and accounts codes, rules of business, etc.) as may apply to a 
variety of sectors, including health, education, and municipal service delivery; 
(ii)  Drawing on the work of the province reform specialists: (a) review all existing 
external agency funded program and projects with either federal or provincial 
executing agencies concerning health, education, municipal services, etc.; and 
(ii) analyze the consistency or otherwise of these modalities with devolution, in 
terms of their scope and assignment of responsibilities for planning, budgeting, 
procurement, and expenditure controls; 
(iii)  Assist  provincial  agencies  responsible  for  the  assigned  sector  identify  the 
implications of the review and identify options for the transition to fully devolved 
systems while ensuring the maintenance of service delivery standards; 
(iv)  Assist province finance commissions design innovative grant systems to create 
incentives (and sanctions) for improved local government performance in service 
delivery; 
(v)  Assist with ongoing activities under the DSP to promote awareness about the 
opportunities  provided  by  devolved  systems  of  service  delivery  among  key 
government stakeholders, donors, and ADB mission leaders through special- 
purpose training and workshop activities and participation in loan supervision and 
processing missions; 
(vi)  Contribute  to  provincial  agencies  engagement  with  design  of  ADB  TAs  and 
lending operations, consistent with the purposes and outputs of the TA; 
(vii)  Assist  provincial  and  local  governments  prepare  and  implement  capacity 
development  activities  to  foster  greater  alignment  of  sector  support  with
